title: Investigating the efficacy of fuzz testing
data:
PTJ Grz - 2025
This thesis explores three aspects of fuzzer efficacy. First, we adapt mutation analysis 
for fuzzer benchmarking. Traditional mutation analysis is computationally prohibitive 
for fuzzers, we contribute optimizations enabling practical benchmarking. We 
validate this approach through an initial evaluation and a fuzzer competition. 
Second, we compare fuzzers and static analysis tools. Measuring bugs detected and 
effort required to act on reported bugs. Results show minimal overlap, justifying using
Cites: Fuzzing: Challenges and Reflections

Cites: Stateful Greybox Fuzzing

massive datasets and CPU-intensive optimizers. Yet has this assumption been 
rigorously tested? The counter-evidence presented in this paper suggests otherwise:
